Big infrastructure projects like this that are shown costing 3x or 4x above the agreed upon price, taking the equivalent multiple in time and then getting framed as a waste of money isn't looking at the big picture. The reality is that no matter what else happens as long as it gets completed, works properly, and has regular users then its impossible for it to not provide an economic boots to the government through more taxes being collected. It's inherently ludicrously expensive to make everyone happy. Paying for mandatory land takeover, paying to keep nature as little disturbed as possible, paying for multiple times the length of required tunnels just to reduce the grades by a tiny bit and allow the trains to run 5% faster. The targets set as non-negotiables were there to reduce the amount that specific people are affected by the project, and as a result everyone pays two-, three,- four-fold in the final bill.  It's both a source of failure and pride. Governments don‚Äôt get money from taxpayers to pay for infrastructure, they print it at the BoE and the growth the infrastructure delivers offsets the dilution of the currency, well thats the theory. If you over build infrastructure you may not reach the growth expectations for your over costed growth like china, or dont build enough like the UK you also may not get the growth expected. So it‚Äôs a delicate balance, now if the government doesn‚Äôt reach the expected growth then the government has to borrow money and put taxes up to pay for the borrowing. Which will be a lot less than the cost of the infrastructure investment as you may hit growth expectations say a year later than expected so you only needed borrowing for 1 year. As infrastructure delivers over a 50yrs and all the cost is front loaded the government is allowed to create capitalised debt which costs next to nothing compared to cash borrowed debt as the capital cost is divided over say 50years by which time inflation reduces the cost of the debt ratio in later year. So its actual cost to tax payers is negligible when discussing infrastructure as long as you don‚Äôt overbuild but build enough to maintain growth.

Responding to this in the aftermath of the recent cancellation of Phase 2: speaking as a Manchester resident, I am positively delighted that HS2 to Manchester has finally been cancelled and it's one of the rare sensible decisions from a government finally grasping the nettle instead of kicking the can down the road.   HS2 was a woeful, misbegotten project right from the word go and it should never have been commissioned.   1)Discounting the statistical anomalies of the microstates like Monaco, the UK is the third most densely-populated country in Europe, behind only Belgium and the Netherlands (both of them still comparatively tiny places). England on its own is the second most dense country in Europe. There was simply never any call for high-speed rail lines in a small, heavily-congested country like ours where the trains would only ever reach top speed for tiny fractions of the journey. Our rail network is often compared unfavourably to the high-speed lines in France and Spain, but France is more than twice the size of the UK while Spain is Europe's 20th most densely populated country. They have longer distances to cover and less people and property to uproot and displace.   2)HS2 is pointless from the outset because it doesn't connect to HS1. Half the reason for making HS2 "HS" to begin with was so that it could tie the UK into the continental high-speed network - it's essentially a European programme in concept. Yet for any European businessman who we're hoping to attract beyond London, his "welcome to Britain" moment is a half-mile trudge in the rain down from St. Pancras to Euston.   3)All the northerners complaining about being "second class citizens" and "abandoning the North", you  have got this backwards. You should frankly be THANKING the Government. HS2 would never have "regenerated the north", all it would have done is been a sap that drains yet more economic activity down to London. Has the TGV made France less centred on Paris? Express lines with no regional/local stops serve no-one except to bring the terminus towns into the capital's commuter belt.  4)HS2's boast that it would improve capacity is overrated - as a grotesquely expensive, horrendously financially incontinent project, tickets would inevitably be massively expensive and the trains would be leaving half-empty, it would never have used to optimal levels and would not have taken much pressure off other lines. Inevitably there would have to be enormous levels of government subsidy to try and cheapen the tickets and fill the trains - yet more horrible waste of money that's urgently needed elsewhere in this crumbling country.   5)Good GOD was the project badly managed - infinite state-funded waste at its most egregious. Even if Phase 2 to Manchester is revived again at a later state, HS2 Ltd. as a company needs to be taken out back and shot and the project needs to be completely rebooted from the ground up with proper oversight and financial control.   That HS2 would have been a big bright shiny new toy for trainspotters to play with is not enough to justify it. Most of the apologists for HS2 make a big deal about the scale of the project, the technology of the trains - like this very video which starts out gushing about how it's "the biggest infrastructure project in the world" - as if we dig holes in the ground for their own sake. I don't care how polished the bogeys are, what problem does it actually solve?   The damage HS2 has already done is bad enough, at least with the cancellation of Phase 2 it can't do any more. I could be persuaded for the need for new rail lines but a new railway could have been built in half the time for a tenth of the cost, with much less environmental damage and more useful servicing of provincial towns, if we had just laid a standard track for normal trains. HS2 was always as ludicrously overengineered as building a nuclear reactor to power a desk lamp. Good riddance to bad rubbish.

There is a difficulty that HSR is rail and maglev is the future likely with double wide and triple level cars traveling at a good fraction of the speed of sound.   This is reasonable development to start by 2045.   This sizing covers a great deal of applications.  Since the 1840s when double track UK railways were designed to occasionally carry double width carriage using the inner rails over double the standard loading gauge has been an attempted ability. ¬†  In a mixed passenger cargo configuration eight meter wide three level maglev trains the first level would likely not be continues between the cars and be a bit noisy due to the maglev motors.  It is sized in width to allow typical automobiles to drive-on-drive-off perpendicular from the sides with enough space around the parked cars for people to walk around them inside the maglev cars.   This configuration allows cargo containers to quickly be loaded and unloaded simultaneously from the sides of the maglev cars.  ¬†  The second and thirst levels would be continues luxury passenger space with vista dome roof sections for passenger to see forward watching the scenery.  This large format maglev passenger train would provide a given number of passengers more comfort in trains 1/4 the length of popular passenger trains of today that stretch out many city blocks.  Cargo only maglev cars would allow large assemblies to be moved overland over great distances easily creating a different and likely better world.

One point not often made is the impact on journey times might not be positive for many.  I live 3~4 miles from the route of HS2, and 2 miles from the current main line. I can get a train to London in ~91 minutes (current timetable). But using HS2 would mean getting to Birmingham and changing there. This is likely to take significantly longer than the saving in time on the HS2 section of the journey.  However, will the current service continue at its current rate, or will our current direct link get slower?  There is the possibility that there will be a direct link on the current network from my local station using HS2 stock, moving on to the HS2 network towards Birmingham. If this happens (how likely this is I am unsure, given the promise of a direct service through the channel tunnel never happened) this might counter the loss, but I suspect the result for us (and most of Staffordshire / Cheshire) will be no gain in journey time over current services, but a significant rise in costs to pay for HS2. The problem isn't simply that people are opposed to new infrastructure - the UK desperately needs new infrastructure. The problem is that this is a service which is essentially designed to move wealthy people around slightly faster. It is not a project designed to help the vast majority of people, but has put a huge burden on the taxpayer in an age of austerity and wage increases below inflation (when they happen at all). *No need for HS2 north of Crewe.*  Currently, the HS2 plan links to the WCML south of Crewe, as the Golborne Link has been dropped. HS2 then running north only serves Manchester. For a few miles from Crewe, north to Minshull Vernon HS2 parallels the WCML, being six tracks wide in total.  Hendy, head of Network Rail, wants the WCML upgraded from Crewe to Preston. From Crewe to Weaver Junction where trains split to Liverpool and Scotland, the 2-track WCML there could be made into 4-track with two tracks being for HS2 classic compatible trains to Liverpool and Scotland ‚Äì but having these tracks still on the WCML, not HS2.  The Crewe North HS2 to WCML junction could remain, allowing Liverpool and Lancaster trains to access Crewe station as already planned under the Crewe Hub scheme.  Non-stop trains would be at full HS2 linespeed of 360kph (223 mph) on the new WCML tracks dedicated to HS2 classic compatible services, with no existing restriction to such speeds. This way, Liverpool and Scotland get ‚Äòfast‚Äô services with Runcorn retaining its London service. Journey times would be similar to HS2 times. All just by making 16 miles of new WCML track 223mph.  Manchester already has a dedicated line to Crewe. Upgrade this and near equal HS2 times are achieved.   HS2 phase 2b will cost ¬£32 billion and rising.  Most of that is for the western leg which *only runs to Manchester.* This is an obscene amount of money serving only one provincial city. Upgrading the WCML north of Crewe, and the Liverpool WCML spur and Manchester WCML spur, can be done for a fraction of the cost of HS2 without needlessly tearing up countryside

The key points are: 1) who will actually use this passenger only line? 2) if it means more people traveling to south east for work than creating work in the north it will have failed; 3) only if large employers move staff from London to the midlands and north is it likely that the former industrial heartland will thrive again with new industries, ideally making use of energy possibilities in old mines, spare space etc as a huge incentive; 4) merely moving such of civil service administrations northwards would not attract new industries because different skills are needed and, in any case, paperwork is more efficiently done electronically; 5) by retaining old gauges instead of having extendable bogies would not make HS2 fast enough to justify the expense; 6) the proposed 'integrated rail' idea floated when Leeds then the offshoot line to Scotland were put on hold would have to be truly integrated and connect with non-HS2 existing lines to attract investment such as is being discussed for north east, north west and Strathclyde rapid transit systems built on the pricing and timetabling structures of these. There is much more need for industries and rapid transit in the north and midlands, Wales and Scotland than the gradually dwindling original HS2 idea -- which began to built in London and should perhaps have started in Birmingham or Crewe.

It's a fascinating project with very interesting questions, most of which will only be answerable once it's fully operational. Certainly in the short term there are work force benefits to providing a project which employs highly skilled staff, but also longer term providing that experience, upskilling and retaining that resource in the UK for the future. Secondly upgrading existing railways, most of which have been severely underfunded for a number of years would be prohibitively expensive in it's own right whilst they're needed to be fully operational, which has to be weighed against the cost of HS2. On the flip side there are real questions to be asked where this will leave the North in 40yrs time, London is and will always big a big draw in terms of employment and life style, I can imagine Birmingham will absorb some of that once it's commutable... The big issue I have with some of the questions is that they seem to be devoid of any real substance, claims that it will scar the landscape don't take into account the reality of these area's already having significant rail and road networks, similarly I'm sure no-one will mention the biodiversity effects once it's built given it's legally obliged to increase net biodiversity. The only real question I think is relevant is how will it contribute to the North/South divide and inequalities in general, but lets face it Northerners may not use it as frequently as Southerners but there is still value to the North, it's just not quite as proportional.

Much of the money spent will be to pay workers who, in turn will buy goods and services supplied by local workers who, in turn, will buy still more goods and services.  Those same workers will pay tax rather than exist on welfare (or, hopefully use less welfare) and will thus contribute to direct economic growth.  The value of the multiplier effect to an economy is usually left out of the argument.  Workers will live in, and buy services from, local businesses and will contribute to shifting money to the north..  There are other less obvious benefits.  The Snowy Mountains scheme in Australia constructed 1946 and 1974 required a serious influx of migration to supply the required skills.  When the project was over not only the skills stayed but so did the the cultures leaving an insular racist nation in a far more successful multicultural state. While a small number of vocal and unpleasant people continue to decry that change most Australians are very happy with the new dimensions those skilled migrants bought to the nation.

The whole HS2 topic is ridiculous... basically that is what happens when vegetables runs the country. The simple question to answer here - is HS2 needed? The answer is likewise simple - yes, it is not only needed urgently, but it is like 50 years LATE. When Europe, in particular France, but as well Spain, Germany, Italy and Netherlands were building high-speed lines the UK was sleeping... the so well known TGV in France was build in 1970s and other countries soon followed. High speed rail is not something new - Shinkansen was build in 1950s in Japan... so all UK is doing is just bringing itself up with times and in "too little too late fashion", if anything HS2 is not enough, they definitely have to run past Manchester and all the way into Scottish at very least reaching Aberdeen and obviously connecting Glasgow with Edinburg. Then they definitely have to going into Vales, branching out to Swansea, Cardiff and Newport. Finally, they should definitely have line going all the way to Cornwall, ideally to very end of it, but high-speed line to at least Plymouth... whenever that this would be branch together with Vales or separate line does not matter. So that is why I am saying too little too late... because realistically this should have been built in 70s, or 80s...   Now the next question - is this worth it and the answer is absolutely, but more detail answer... it is worth the money it is worth, not the stupid ¬£100 billion... wo we need to understand why it happened... and this is because we allow vegetables to get in the way of public interest. Should the environment be considered? Yes it should... but it should be considered in planning process and THAT IS IT. Once the plan is approved, there should be no provisions for protesting, this is project of national importance and it should be treated as such. Parliament has dropped the ball on this, they should have had something like "HS2 bill" stating that trespassing on the project or preventing or delaying it in any way is criminal offence - end of story. The reality is that all these protests now should not be allowed to even happen. We looked at the project, we mitigated obvious environmental issues, now let's get on with it. Likewise the supporting legal framework should have included mandatory purchase of land for the project i.e. nobody should have a power no to sell-up at fair market value. What I am saying - if this project being of national importance would have received the required response from national government then we wouldn't have seen so much delays and so much cost overruns... now we literally changing the route of national project because some vegetables are chaining themselves to the trees... look just leave them chained to the tree for a week and I am sure they will change their mind themselves.   So in conclusion this project costs and delays are spiralling out of control, because we allow idiots to get in the way of it... surely there were many bad project management decisions, like for example starting the build before the required land was purchased... as result increasing the price of that land once people realised they can bargain with government. It was better to secretly purchase all the worthless farming land in the way and only then announce what it will be used for. In short - mistakes happened, but that doesn't mean the project itself is not required or that it was bad idea.

It's a fascinating project with very interesting questions, most of which will only be answerable once it's fully operational. Certainly in the short term there are work force benefits to providing a project which employs highly skilled staff, but also longer term providing that experience, upskilling and retaining that resource in the UK for the future. Secondly upgrading existing railways, most of which have been severely underfunded for a number of years would be prohibitively expensive in it's own right whilst they're needed to be fully operational, which has to be weighed against the cost of HS2. On the flip side there are real questions to be asked where this will leave the North in 40yrs time, London is and will always big a big draw in terms of employment and life style, I can imagine Birmingham will absorb some of that once it's commutable... I think a lot of the problem with projects like this (including California HSR) is that it just costs way more to do something like this as a one off or for the first time, without any prior experience, than it does for established industries in other countries. You're not just paying for the project itself, but also to build and train everything and everyone involved, and there is a lot of experimentation and inefficiency inherent to that process. So when you make an estimate by looking at per mile costs in the rest of Europe, it's wildly inaccurate. The key to doing this kind of infrastructure development sustainably seems to be never stopping.
It seems like the main issue with this project is the dishonest initial assessment of costs. The question is then if that was due to negligence or actual malice.
An interesting example (which could make a great video?) of where government has actually thrown in the towel and abandoned a megaproject is the Superconducting Super Collider in Texas, where the US spent several billion dollars digging what ended up as only a big (22km!) hole in the ground.
A plan that had everybody gasping; at the sheer scale of the project and, of course, the huge cost. How do we justify spending so much public money on what many see as a vanity project yet leave the building of nuclear power stations to foreign companies? Those foreign companies have built-in guarantees to be allowed to charge whatever they like when the power comes on stream. So the British public is shafted time and time again. As for HS2, the promised gains for travellers are already being amended. The finished article will bear no resemblance to the promised utopia.

There are always huge benefits to these infrastructure projects, and sure, generally afterwards the public forget about the inconvenience and loss while the people badly affected move on and stop shouting about it. However, that doesn't mean what has actually been lost has been compensated for, or that the economic advantages have been worth the overall cost. This is an equation that every infrastructure project faces, but there is always a real possibility they will come down on the "not worth it" side. Such projects can end up only significantly benefiting a small segment of the then-current population, or come with enormous environmental costs, or the benefits are just an increase in convenience that people really don't need. People will always move in to take advantage of new opportunities, but who needed this project today and what price are those people paying?   Certainly stopping the project halfway through won't help anything, but critical parts of the project might need to change according to external factors, too. What does the balancing equation say about this project? I don't know, but I suggest experts in the relevant issues involved should scrutinise every aspect just in case changes do need to be made.  Generally at the moment, for all these big projects, the environmental cost is the most concerning. For example, planting trees to replace what has been lost is a good start, but you're not replacing the forest ecosystem that has been lost, nor the wildlife that lives there, and you need to plant the right indigenous tree species too. So, this isn't a simple situation, and that's just one example, while climate change is the big concern. The carbon footprint of these big infrastructure construction projects is huge and must be accounted for in the environmental cost-benefit analysis.¬†Many countries are building these big infrastructure projects now, but what is the overall effect on our carbon emissions, and should we even be investing in new projects when we are struggling with critical environmental issues? Shouldn't we at least delay these projects until we have a handle on this global crisis (at least organisationally)? If we're not careful, we might end up screwing up the climate so badly that we need brand new different infrastructure in a few decades.

In the Anglosphere, in the 21st century, infrastructure projects are make work projects. As manufacturing moved to East Asia, Western governments needed a way to employ former manufacturing workers, and the only low-skilled, labour intensive industry that remained was construction. So all over the Anglosphere we have housing booms and enormous, horrifically expensive infrastructure projects with no demonstrable value to society. The goal is to employ blue collar workers, enrich party donors who own construction companies and for politicians to get rich on graft and kickbacks.  ¬£100B is 66GW of installed solar. Equivalent to about a third of the UK's electricity consumption. But that industry is far too distributed to earn graft from.

Firstly - two personal things about HS2 - 1/ I love BIG PROJECTS 2/ the Chiltern Tunnel has been bored directly under the family homestead. From the very first thoughts HS2 cut down entire forests just to supply their beautiful paperwork! Normally, when you get a notification under the Planning laws - it arrives on a standard bit of council bog roll and that's it; however; HS2 seem to want to out do the Russian artillery - great wodges of their stuff has cascaded through my letterbox, as it has done to everyone anywhere near the route. There are letters, glossaries explaining their words, processes, method statements and wonderful brochures and copious maps included every flipping time - I've stacked up mine in a pile and it now amounts to more than two reams of photocopy from OfficeWorld. Not that any of it is actually photocopy - it's all printed - they're all a work of art and I suspect a small army of such artisans are gainfully employed designing the next lot as I write!  Though now retired, I've been in construction virtually all my life ( my dad was a General Foreman so I spent time on sites in the 1950's ) I ended up running medium sized projects ( my dad didn't live long enough to see me make Site Agent - one leg up from him!) most of them difficult or in trouble. I've been  invited and visited the Chiltern Viaduct but I'm sure - jealous of the much better access they afforded to young Fred here - I expect the approaching 3 mill views and subscribers helped with that! All the reasons FOR one were quickly made to cancel out any against, at least enough to wind up the clockwork. We've not built a high speed railway till now because our cities and towns aren't very far apart - and most importantly - there's so much stuff already in the way! Too bad that nothing about the expected return is mentioned. So the project costs 100BN, let's say the train only goes from London to Crewe. If the train rides 3x per hour, from 6h to 24h, both ways (x2), 365 days a year, then there are 39,420 train rides a year, let's round this up to 40,000 times. If the train's capacity is 1000 people, ticket prices are 200 pounds, and if they manage to make a profit of 20%, then they make a total profit of 40,000 pound per train ride. At 40,000 train rides a year, each train ride having a profit of 40,000, then the yearly profit is 1.6BN.   This would mean that the high speed train ride is profitable after 62,5 years.   I'm just pulling these number out of my arse, so no idea if that's a realistic number

The issue is that they build project like this in the wrong order. Instead of starting with the part furthest away, they would remove the option of re-thinking a project in such a way like this, were the promises just fall apart. When the furthest away stretches are built it is highly unlikely that a project then will get abandoned. What might happen is that the cost is saved by finding a way to connect the outskirts, of the largest city to the center, rather than having the high speed train continue, while still offering great benefits. After all, some of the use will be connecting people to an important airport, and others that work in London in this case, actually don't need to get to the center. But the city and the outskirts might get updated infrastructure project that still decreases the travel time, compared to existing solution, thus making the difference less than expected when the project was first started. And if commuter lines can be opened connecting the smaller cities at first, those regions gets to experience the benefits, and the project will get a more positive reception. London, while having a housing crisis like many other bigger cities around the world, still is a strong functioning economical zone, the biggest advantages actually comes from growing the economic activities in other areas, and that is not necessarily by connecting more people to London and have people commute out of London for cheaper housing, it might actually come from several of smaller cities being more connected. Connecting cities outside of London, actually comes with a risk of hurting local businesses, but if those first get a boost from becoming connected to other cities, the economic zone between all those cities might actually become strong enough to survive the risk of connecting them to London. And at the end of the day, it is however much more likely that the project will end up fulfilling all the promises of reach made initially, if the last bit comes down to whether or not the station will be in central London, or in the outskirts, compared to the smaller cities further away, or on the way, that are typically cut in projects like this, or the start and finish is in total delayed by decades.

WELL PRESENTED  This is a well presented video covering HS2.  The costings of HS2 are clearly increasing far beyond those of any other major infrastructure project and will continue to do so. It is an ill thought out project which has merely inspired politicians of every political hue to 'want a slice of the pie'....  The continuing fights over the routes north of Birmingham, where cities are falling over themselves to have it pass through, or nearby, to them.....plus the myriad MP's who want it to pass through their constituencies, (and with a station too please), confirms this for us on a daily basis.  Starting it south to north or vice-versa is of little consequence in the grand order of things, though clearly the London Centric mode of thinking is ever present where infrastructure is concerned.  That the final route was not determined before even the first sod was cut tells us all much of what we need to know. The fact that there has been no complete assessment of the soil structure along the full route defines the matter even further.  It is one thing to run into unexpected soil and ground conditions, as you go...and once the ground has been surveyed. It is another thing completely to just come across things and then simply state that 'conditions are challenging'....or some similar such phrase....  There are cost implications when plans go awry because something unexpected has been found, and there are increased costs simply because the project is 'winging it'....  Sadly, there would appear to be considerable elements of the latter with HS2.  Sold on the rather dubious...and clearly incalculable basis of 'Benefits to the Economy'.....and at a time when, through increased inter-connectivity, we have less need to travel for business, it is hard to fathom the logic of spending so much money merely to reduce the London - Birmingham travel time by less than 40 minutes, and the London - Leeds travel times by less than 30 minutes.  Hardly enough time to serve a train full of passengers a cup of coffee....!  HS2 is being portrayed as putting the UK back at the front of Railway Development. It is, of course a nonsense since it implies catching-up with the rest of the world. This is being portrayed as 'Speed'....err, well, Higher Speed.... as the desirable aim.  Rather interestingly this portrayal of 'Speed' for its own sake does not stand up on the World Railway Stage....and has to be applied to comparisons with Europe. Leaving aside the fact that 'Catching-up with Europe' is a meaningless concept....but hey, there you go..!  The basic flaw in all those projects which seek to increase train speeds across the UK, is that no consideration is ever given to what the best optimal train speeds should be. Everything seems to be determined on just calling for faster speeds.  Much of this stems from the concept of the Privatisation of the Railways when the majority of the operators coming new to the railway scene were bus operators. Whilst they had no idea of just what it meant to run a railway, they did rapidly discern that the railways were just another form of bus service....and one which if it could go faster...and stop less frequently...would pay dividends.  So it has come to pass...  Leaving aside major long distance routes, of which there are relatively few, there is hardly anywhere in the UK that is more than 90 miles from the sea. As such, this equates to a more than acceptable top speed, for most trains; something that can be achieved with line and route upgrades.  A case can be made for longer distance trains to travel within 100 MPH plus and sub 140 MPH speeds....but that is more than enough.  It is more than adequate that Manchester / Liverpool - Euston, and Leeds / York - Kings + take approximately two and a half hours. Any and such improvements upon this can and should be achieved using a mixture of line and route upgrades, AND, an improved mix of stopping, semi-fast and non-stop trains.  Sadly, the cost of even the most minor of upgrades is now costing what has so far been spent on HS2, (¬£15B), with costs escalating with every project.  Even the simplest of line improvements, (a quarter mile or so with track and signalling changes), costs ¬£7M.....whilst the most basic of new stations comes in at around ¬£3m.  Much of the increasing costs for new stations comes from the fixation with the Disability Discrimination / Compliance provision, where we can expect to see stations built with expensive lifts at every turn.  Little thought is given to location and the consideration that relatively easy access can be given to platforms without the need for lifts. The answer is to put in lifts to start with...so a couple of ¬£Million without blinking everttime.  HS2 is a 'Vanity Project'....something beloved of our modern political elites. They are in the hole they have dug for themselves and they keep digging. More money is the answer.  Attendant to this is the continuing fixation with so-called Carbon reduction ..and Carbon Neutral travel. It is a small step towards controlling the way in which people will be allowed to travel....and to regulating them more if they do.  Those who promote 'Vanity Projects' cannot countenance failure. Failure is a sign of weakness....or more accurately, (if they wish to consider it), that they might have been wrong from the outset.  Nobody has the courage and political will to say enough has been spent.  I take the view....and only time will prove if I am right or wrong....that HS2 costs will very easily reach ¬£200B....and could well head considerably north of that figure towards ¬£500B.  But hey, what do I know...?  James Hennighan Yorkshire, England

Stuttgart 21 renews the railway track plan around Stuttgart entirely to get rid of the terminus station and have a pass through central station instead, but it is not a high speed line. However, it is a masterpiece of engineering and there is a brand new high speed line between Ulm and Wendlingen near Stuttgart where it meets the new Stuttgart 21-tracks. This line has to be seen in an European context because it is part of a high speed connection between western and eastern Europe. Train drivers receive their Streckenkunde-Training in these days, so they get to know the new tracks, signalling and other provisions made for safe traveling.

I live in a township thats growing by the day, we already saw a huge population increase a few years back and we are still riding that wave. Our current only public transport is a Bus Network that depending on the time you are taking the bus can take different amounts of time. The is BusA, a direct bus which only goes to 3 stops in the township and drop off at 3 hubs in the city (2 CBD edge and central). BusB, the 'express' bus takes BusC's route but is only support to pickup when going into the city to a point and after that point its drop off - its not any faster than C in most cases. BusC, standard route, goes through our township then the next one over then into the city. BusA is really the only bus I want to be taking but they only have limited times of running that bus, from 6am-8am and 3:40pm-5:40pm. The slight issue is that for a lot of people, though this is the best bus, its outside their travel times, meaning they have to take either B or C which can be double the time of A.  I would love to see our train operational because it also means we can run to the Rural towns as well, who have 0 public connection to my township meaning they need to drive in, and it would be a quick system. As a regular TGV user in France (especially the Paris - Bordeaux Line) there are no doubt real benefits with high speed rail. I always find these type of programmes frustrating as they don‚Äôt delve into the details and include talking heads who really don‚Äôt say very much that is useful. As a result you can‚Äôt really have a meaningful view of the project. On the question of whether the project will continue if costs continue to escalate it seems extremely unlikely that the government would pull the plug unless something utterly astonishing were to happen. I‚Äôm not sure for projects of this type that are financed by the public sector whether any detailed business case is presented with meaningful estimates, assumptions & risks and whether there is any expectation of a payback period. It would be interesting how HS1 progressed as a project and whether a post implementation review was conducted. Anyway by 2029 it seems we are going to end up with a new line for passenger traffic only between London Euston (New terminus with 10 platforms) & Birmingham Curzon St with stops at Old Oak Common & Solihull Interchange and with trains running up to 225mph.  I have a number of questions / assumptions (some of which can‚Äôt be answered at present) : Is Curzon St a terminus with no further travel possible to (say) New St ? If so is there a tram line to get passengers to other parts of the city ?  If I was travelling from London to (e.g.) Wolverhampton would I change at Solihull Interchange or should I just go on the slow train from London using the existing line ?  For the new line to attract customers what will be the cost of tickets in relation to existing service? Who are the types of customers they are looking to attract ? Commuters (amongst others) ?   No doubt the franchise will be run by a private rail company or will there be more than one operator ?  Are existing trains capable of reaching speeds of 225mph ?  What is the likely maximum number of carriages they going to have ?  In terms of freeing up capacity on the existing West Coast mainline this only will be of benefit from Rugby (where Birmingham trains branch off via Coventry) to Euston section and presumes the existing London to Birmingham service is reduced (how bust is it just now ?). The programme indicated there was minimal scope for adding further services on the mainline as things currently stand. This appears to be one of the big selling points and needs to be clarified.  In terms of economic benefits, the regeneration of the area around Curzon St will obviously boost that local area but where specifically are the expected economic benefits to come from ? It‚Äôs not as though  there were no existing links between the two cities. The reference to helping reduce the house prices / housing crisis seems ludicrous.  In terms of environmental benefits there was no reference to the (negative) impact of the construction and no detail on how operationally the line will be decarbonised. Are we going to see domestic commercial flights scrapped between the two cities (as France has done on domestic rules).  Will there be a push for more freight to go by rail (if capacity is available) ?  Having some further details on the above (plus I‚Äôm sure others could think of a lot more areas to question) might at least give people some means of seeing whether this is a worthwhile project or a white elephant.

The basic economic idea of HS2 is that the South East has a very strong and growing economy, and the North does not. By improving the connection between them, the two entities will become closer. By making places like Birmingham and Crewe as easy to get to from London as Reading or Milton Keynes, it will make the former more like the latter. (The introduction of Broadband internet should have had a similar effect, particularly after the greater acceptance of things like Zoom.)  While the planned engineering and environmental changes to be brought about by the HS2 project are fairly well covered, the planned economic changes to the North could be better covered in this video. That is the main measure to weigh the frequently mentioned costs against.  (Also, if a major benefit of the project is reducing CO2 emissions, some comment on how much it's expected to do so is quite warranted.)

Costs for long term projects like this always go up.  They are costed at the price for things at the time the costs are estimated.  Inflation drives costs upwards, so anyone criticising the rising costs is simply not grasping the concept of inflation.  Also, any unforeseen issues, which inevitably arise with any big project will drive costs up.  No large scale infrastructure project has ever come in at the original cost.  To suggest they should is just naive.

I don't necessarily disagree with HS2 but I think there is a sort of general acceptance that it won't actually reach the North, let alone Scotland. Predictably, it started down South, prioritising travel between Birmingham and London. It was planned to have gone as far North as Leeds, as part of phase 2b, which was predictably cancelled. Given it is currently possible to get to London to Birmingham by train in almost an hour and a half, and regional inequality is so bad in Britain, you do have to wonder why it was started where it was. Why not make the Northern towns and cities better connected to each other? The rail link from Newcastle to Cumbria is pretty dreadful, as are plenty of other places which are being willfully neglected.   Alternatively, why not improve public transport in a Northern city or two? The aforementioned Leeds is home to around half a million people, about the same size as Leipzig in Germany. While Leipzig has no underground railway network, it has an extensive tram system. Leeds has neither. Why?   And I have to be honest, even when the Leeds phase was planned, it still feels like the North was being fobbed off. I mean, Leeds is about 100 miles from Newcastle, the most Northern city of England, which is to say nothing of Northumberland, the largest county in England, another area where rail travel is a pipe dream in a lot of places.   All public transport construction projects go wildly over budget. When the final bill comes in for that project, just ask yourself if it really was money well spent. And this is without considering the rail intrastructure in Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales. I'm sure those from those places will have similar stories.

Any time you plan a project, you should expect the following.  Whatever your realistic estimates on time and cost are, taking into account all foreseeable engineering, environmental and political challenges, triple them.  You now have your low estimate for actual time and cost upon completion of the project.  Now triple it again to get an upper estimate.  The actual cost should be somewhere within the range of the two, usually around 5.5x the original planned budget.   If the project comes in under triple the original planned cost and sooner than triple the planned duration, investigate to find out where corners have been cut.

19:15 "2B or Not 2B" üòÇ
A simple cost-benefit analysis made it look like a good investment with the initial projected cost, but a poor one with the actual cost. A better investment of ~¬£80bn would be setting up a sovereign wealth fund, like what Norway did with its oil money. That could deliver, on average, about ¬£50 per person per year (inflation-adjusted) indefinitely. But since this money is raised through regular taxation anyway, it may be better to give the ~¬£1000 per person to citizens directly for them to spend or invest as they see fit.  With so much of leg 1 already built, though, it may be worth continuing investment, since the cost of completing that leg is now lower than it would be had none of it been built.  One thing I'm yet to see is how the need for high-capacity rail along that route has changed since we vastly reduced our coal use around 2014. Coal (for power stations) used to make up a large chunk of rail freight in the UK. Now it's largely gone, did they factor that into the calculation of the benefit of increased capacity along the HS2 route?

one important factor is the history of high speed travel in the west of britain    in the 1970s, the rest of europe and japan decided that the way to improve transportation was to build dedicated high speed rail lines to connect city centers.  at the same time, the US was building highways and slashing rail service, while britain slashed local service (beeching report) and also decided to create high speed rail by compromising and building the APT so they could have fast service on existing tracks on the west coast mainline.  This was supposedly a way to build better connections on the cheap, and it was a colossal failure.  since britain wasted time on this project, they fell behind the curve of HSR.    now, HS2 is an attempt to catch up by building a railway with the fastest speeds in europe.  and instead of recognizing that this is a catch-up, britain is bitching and moaning about the cost of building a proper railway, just like they did in the 70s.  they're cutting back the efficacy of the project for austerity reasons, and will pay for it for generations to come, just like people are paying now for the decisino 50 years ago to not build HS2 and instead waste a generation on the APT.  moral of the story, the best time to build a high speed railway was 40 years ago, the next best time is today.

Fascinating. Bit of a sidenote, but the UK's HS2 is actually almost exactly the same size, scope, and cost as California's HSR project... except with actual political willpower and funding behind it. Sad to think that CA's project could, perhaps, be at a similar level of progress, IFF it were actually funded, and politically supported by the CA state legislature. As opposed to waiting for a handout from the federal govt (which seems incredibly unlikely to happen at this point), and just working on the ~$10B IOS that CA actually has the funding to build, and doing preliminary engineering / environmental impact reports on everything else. Incl the expensive-AF tunnels to LA etc that are needed to actually make the full project work...  All other thoughts / criticisms / etc seem equally applicable to both projects, but there's a massive, massive difference between having the PM(s) of your country constantly advocate / push for HS2, and having CA's HSR get little to no political support, and face continual attempts by CA's state legislature to kill it and/or redirect its funding elsewhere. And face constant journalistic hit-jobs every 5 minutes by the LA Times et al to attempt to cancel it   $100B for a high speed rail line isn't excessive, or too expensive. That quite simply what a modern infrastructure project costs, in a modern developed country, in the 21st century. And it's cheaper than the alternatives, ie. freeway expansion, airport expansion, etc  Watching this happen in the UK is super cool, but it's sad to think that we could be doing the same, but still currently lack the political willpower to do the same thing here, even in what is quite literally the most liberal / green / pro-environment state in the US, and that COULD, of all US states, afford to build a $100B infrastructure project by itself (see the recent ~$100B CA budget surplus, for instance ‚Äì what we decided to do with that instead is just depressing)

Would it be easier to build new lines along the routes of the old lines, sharing past land acquisitions.  Thus additional tracks would be within a few meters of the old ones except where shortening a few corners and zig-zags. Lots of controversy surrounded the construction of the SGR from Nairobi to Mombasa covering a distance of 472km. Initially, it took over 12hrs using the old metre gauge railway and 6-7hrs using the road.  Now most kenyans can enjoy a relatively faster travel time from those two cities.  Project was plagued by cost overruns with no delays, many questioned the governments decision to award a Chinese company the contract citing hefty debts owed to China but years after completion, people are beginning to appreciate the value of the infrastructure project.  Though not a high speed electric train, the line has eased the pressure on road transport by removing over a thousand trucks and buses on the and reduced fatal road accidents on the northern corridor.

This is an issue I have regarding a Unicameral government v. a federal government.  With a Unicameral government all or a significant amount of funding comes from the National government.  Thus, the localities remain dependent upon the National government for funding.  A Federal government, localities are not necessarily dependent upon National funding.  The localities can tax themselves or sell bonds to fund public projects.  If Northern England and Scotland want to fund this rail service, then maybe they create a Public Authority which is able to levy taxes and sell construction bonds.  Otherwise, the hinterlands and the less populated areas up north will not receive their expected funding.

Original estimates in the 80's were around ‚Ç¨340 million, later corrected to ‚Ç¨1,1 billion back in the early 90's. The original budget was set on ‚Ç¨2,4 billion and the final cost came in at ‚Ç¨4,7 billion. Prof. dr. Bent Flyvbjerg conducted a study on the cost overruns, one of his conclusions was that the complexity of these projects is almost always underestimated while the policy makers have some sort of misplaced overconfidence/optimism. Yeah the mistake was starting from London. Let's prioritize the most expensive per mile portion. They probably should have started from Glasgow. People do the same thing when discussing high speed rail in the US. They all focus on the asoa express in the Northeast. Or through the most expensive real estate in California. Meanwhile between the Mississippi River and California there are many cities that are in the Goldilocks zone for High-Speed Rail between 200 and 700 miles apart with mostly government-owned land or Farmland between them. These projects really need to start looking at the cost per mile and getting the low hanging fruit done first. We try to do the hardest bits that in many ways are the least suitable for High-Speed Rail and then it fails and goes over budget and nobody believes in high speed rail anymore. The high-speed rail from San Francisco shouldn't be headed towards Los Angeles it should be headed toward Yosemite Las Vegas the Grand Canyon Zion's National Park Salt Lake City Denver Phoenix Etc. Instead they've decided to stop every 30 to 60 miles right through the heart of urbanized California. It's going to be over budget and it's not going to function all that well because nobody wants to train coming through their town if it's not going to stop. Let's focus on the low hanging affordable fruit then we can connect the more difficult sections to the network. That's the kind of thinking that is going to get high speed rail done. It's not going to get done by building the most expensive lines first.

There‚Äôs a big difference between spending decisions by a Government versus a private sector company on a big project, namely the cyclical nature of spending, income and taxes. This $100B will primarily be spent locally in the UK, on labour, equipment and land purchase - with immediate financial benefit to the receiver, who pays tax on this income and generally will go on to spend the bulk of the rest (locally in the UK for the most part) allowing the cycle to continue. So the cost of this project not only returns infrastructure with future potential, but represents investment in people and the economy today (to the broad benefit of the tax payer footing the initial bill).

Under the circumstances, HS2 is and always was, IMO, a complete waste of money.   When it was first announced, it was claimed that it'd reduce travel times between cities (fair enough) and would also offer internet connection so that people could work whilst on the train.    Which seemed a peculiar argument to me as if people can work via the internet on a train, then they can do so from home as well. Add to that, the cost of travelling by rail long distance in the UK is so high that only the already wealthy can afford it. as a reguar thing  So who was this project supposed to be benefitting again?   Now, I am not against infrastructure projects, far from it. Old infrastructure needs to be maintained or replaced, and occasionally new infrastructure needs to be built if the extant system is overloaded. I simply do not see the point of HS2. Particuarly when there's been a far more pressing need, this last several decades, to reshape agriculture and rewild as much land as possible, to help combat climate change and ecosystem collapse.  It's all very well encouraging people to eat less meat (because it's a very inefficient way of feeding people), but you can't just throw livestock farmers under a bus.   The billions spent on HS2 could be supporting farmers to change to ecologically more sound farming practices, as well as public education campaigns to encourage people to shift towards plant-based diets and away fro eat-eating, extra money to the NHS, education and the Armed Forces (particularly the army).  Then there's things like the water infrastructure. OK, so some level of leakage is inevitable,  but from what I;v heard, the leakage losses in some parts are enormous.  Consideration on ways to dimiinsh evaporative losses would be good too, the more so as we are likely to be in drought conditions more and more often. Research into how to create buildings that require as litte power for cooling during heatwaves as possible, as well as research into personal cooling devices could be encouraged.   All of which is far more important than reducing the travel time between London and the rest of the UK.  Economic benefits of HS2? So far as I can see, they all assume "business as usual" (and even then I don't find them that convincing), but climate change means that business won't be as usual. Warmer wetter winters, and hotter drier summers with less predictable weather will cripple agriculture, greatly reducing its ability to feed people both in terms of numbers of people and the reliability of supply. So investment in things like vertical farming is needed on a large scale and should have been started years ago. If the populace cant be adequately fed, what follows as a result will be economic disaster,  whether HS2 exists or not.   I like trains, and public transport in general, I'd like to see more public transport and fewer cars on the road; more movement of goods by rail and less by lorry, where possible.  Heck, I even feel that we will probably need a few new modern nuclear power stations (Thorium hot salt, perhaps?) to ensure a stable base load is available.  So I'm no Luddite. It's just that the amount of money allocated to HS2 could have been better spent on stuff that , unlike HS2, is vital to stave off environmental and economic collapse.

The real problem with our railways here in the UK is NOT speed . It is Capacity & Loading Gauge. Because Gt Britain had the earliest locomotive worked railway system in the World we have suffered from a very old infrastructure base. George & Robert Stephenson realised that the  railway was not some sort of "Sophisticated Canal"  Parliament however didn't really understand the new technology. Robert Stephenson did his best to build the WCML as well as he could in the 1830's.But he did not fully realise  how big rolling stock could be even on Std gauge 4' 8 & half"/1435mm  But because our railways were so early they were small.  With narrow and low carriages.  It is almost a truism to say that it was a good job early locomotives like 'Rocket' had such tall chimneys because if they hadn't the loading gauge would have been even smaller! Double Deck carriages are common in Europe and the US. The only double deck carriages in the UK on mainline use since WWII were two four car electric sets running from Dartford into London. These cramped and uncomfortable trains which were built to the limit of the loading gauge Being withdrawn in 1971. However because the loading gauge in Europe allows for higher and wider carriages double deck carriages are comfortable and pleasant to use.  Another issue is that in Europe and the US is that lorries can be easily loaded on flat bed bogies. As a result of this lorry carrying trains run for long distances ie Italy to Germany. In the US lorries are also carried for long distances.  This is impossible in the UK and HST 2 will allow lorry carrying trains keeping the lorries off the roads . Also HST will allow ordinary European freight rolling stock to opperate into the UK which will be very useful for rail freight. The  other issues is capacity.  The WCML is at maximum loading capacity. It is worth noting that most long distance trains stopped at Watford Junction. Now they don't because there is not enough time due to the line now running at near 100% capacity.  The real question should be  "Not Can We Afford To Build HST More Can We Not Afford To Build HST" It is also worth noting the problems that men like George & Robert Stephenson and I K Brunel faced in the 19th Century building the original lines. Thank you very much for a really interesting instructive video.

Modern train attempts remind me of old ocean liners. From occasional crossings with wooden ships eventually birth was given to proper ocean liners, first aiming to be the fastest and later evolving to be slower, bigger, more comfortable and more reliable running a set schedule. Ocean liners were then repurposed to cruise ships and replaced by airplanes as aviation caught on. And this feels to me like a similar evolution with trains. Trains came evolving to be more practical, more affordable, heavier, faster and more comfortable only to be pushed to the side lines by planes and cars. In places they still hold the top since they can provide better service than any other vehicle in those regions but there is a question if it isn't just the beginning of the end for the train, just like it was for horses and ocean liners.

A big part of this project has been the archaeological work too. Though often the unseen side of infrastructure, the growth to the commercial archaeological industry has been immeasurable. Companies have felt safe taking on more archaeologists full time making it a truly reliable job for the first time. The HS2 induced growth has meant all construction led archaeology has become faster, cheaper and more advanced as investment in people and technology has increased. This can even be seen by how MOLA (the company who gained the most from HS2) was able to buy a rival company and has grown from 3 offices nation wide to 6. They also have followed the paperless initiative to digitise and modernise the stagnant recording methods with new technologies meaning all archaeology work will be of a higher quality and faster in the long run.  In this sense HS2 is already giving back to the country in unseen ways without even needing to be complete. Even with the explanations in the video, I still have a hard time figuring out where all those cost overruns go... Especially when compared to 2 other recent high-speed lines in neighboring countries : France's Tours <> Bordeaux line (~300km) that extended the Paris <> Tours line while bypassing every city in between and still serving them with branches. This was a private concession of public infrastructure, with all the environmental bells and whistles like wetland ponds, myriads of planted trees, wildlife over / underpasses, etc. Crossing less densely inhabited locations but prime wine yards and other expensive grounds, large rivers and complicated soil. Spain's Madrid < 630km 2h30 > Barcelona < 195km 50min > Perpignan (in France, through a twin bored high-speed tunnel under the base of the Pyrenees mountain range) that also bypasses every city served by the line, including Barcelona, by either running on cities' outskirts (and branching to serve centers) or running in a high-speed tunnel under cities). A very complicated hilly / mountainous terrain, etc. How come they managed to build these lines for a fraction of the ever-growing cost of HS2 ? I know they are different but each have their difficulties and I really can't see what justifies such massive budget ballooning for HS2 ! I'm a little surprised they did not tell of 'an interesting situation' that arose early on when digging at the Euston end.... a digger driver noticed what he thought were bones and so called his boss who took a look who called 'his boss'.... there were lots of bones all over the place. Naturally they were duty bound to call the police who came down to have a look...an old experienced detective suggested they go and get some people from the local university to take a look. It turned out they had disturbed a burial site from the London Plague days of the late 1600's. For the next three months the site was cordoned off and dozens of volunteers from the university and other local institutes removed all the bones photographed them and re-interred them elsewhere...these movements were always carried out in the early hours of the mornings. Apparently, in this area of Euston/Kings Cross many tens of thousands of people died from the Bubonic Plague... A colleague of mine who worked in an overlooking Islington Clinic told me about the goings on which took about three months to complete.   An interesting HS2 snippet!

There is an easy way to figure out if something like this is worth it. First, you need to take the cost savings of time, how many minutes saved by passengers (How many passengers times how many trips = how many hours) and multiple that by the hourly wage. This will show the savings. Then you need to figure out the cost of the project. If you take the savings and divide it by the cost you get return on investment. Now this number is not complete, but is a great starting point. Since the savings is only around a half hour per person, and there is already a good normal train route, covering this route chances are very high this project will never be worth while. Once you figure out the cost and the benefit you need to compare that to other returns (like how much money you would get if you invest in the stock market). Generally, a cost of capital should be 6 to 10%. (That is what one can get in other investments.  It probably would be cheaper to upgrade the existing train route, make longer trains, more train cars, increase speeds, and create a better experience. Having traveled all around the world, on various train systems, it is vary rare that they are truely worthwhile. It takes a very high density in order to make mass transit make sense. This project probably increased costs greatly by trying to dig under forests. Those decisions likely increased the cost by crazy numbers (like $200,000 per tree saved). Other ways one can increase value on a route like this can be by creating a better experience. Times on trains can be used to eat, workout, have meetings ect.

"spreading wealth" is where HS2 gets itself into trouble. What it does is connect a bunch of large, already wealthy, already well-connected and serviced cities together. The worst-case scenario is it is actually successful and creates a London-Birmingham-Manchester megalopolis, and the best case scenario is it makes relatively not-wealthy people pay for a very very very expensive train system that knocks a few minutes off journey times and trashes large corridors of major cities. There was a better way - you take a line that runs up the country but is less used and in an appropriate location (Midland Main Line, anybody?) and upgrade it then create an integrated rail network by upgrading the other parts of the network - there are places without electrified lines, there are places that still use semaphore signalling, there are lines that use the most awful rolling stock, here are really obvious junctions on the main lines that cause major traffic issues; but alas the government didn't want to know because the government (or rather successive governments) wanted a nameplate project rather than an integrated transport network that actually works. HS2 is why when Boris got himself into trouble he went looking for friends and found the political support cupboard was bare - what he should have done is on the day he came to power immediately stopped the thing, cancelled all the contracts and put somebody on the task of doing it right - if he'd done that he wouldn't be looking around for a new job. The real sting in the tail of HS2 isn't going to be that it's going to make large rail projects politically impossible for decades, it isn't going to be it's final monetary cost - it's going to be the harm it does to other well-functioning rail lines that will become financially infeasible and should have got financial support instead - like the East Coast Mainline which don't have much of a future, but people rely on to commute to and attend meetings, use for leisure travel etc, the costs of these services will rocket, if they continue to exist in years to come. What's worse still is that there's a _strong_ chance of rail becoming moot technology within the next 20 years anyway; by the time this is all done there's every chance other countries will be quickly building hyperloop systems to catch up anyway or that driverless vehicles+EVs will completely ruin the value of rail and we'll be stuck paying the bill for this nonsense - there was a way forward, upgrade and improve what we have and hold and wait on the nameplate project, see which way the wind blows over the next 10 years.

My big problems with HS2 are that it is little more than a vanity project, and capacity would have been improved better by removing chokepoints on the existing network, like the Welwyn bottleneck on the East Coast Main Line, to identify just one, particularly glaring example. Then there is the "democratic process" of approval when we were given the choice of yes or yes, as both major parties were in favour, and no feasible vote was available against it. And unless ticket prices are set to a far more reasonable level than rail travel prices at present, it will only be of benefit to the wealthiest among us. The balance of the cost of this vanity project would have been far better spent on, for example, complying with the UN decision on the UK's failure to meet its obligations to those with disabilities, which the Conservatives just shrugging and saying effectively "so what are you going to do about it" and carrying on with the systemic institutional abuse of the most vulnerable in society, just to give tax cuts to the wealthiest. The timing of this massive project could not possibly be worse. Japan is held up as the shining example of a costly project that became a focal point of national pride, but that was built when there wasn't a better alternative in the works. Also- Japan's high speed rail connects cities that are absolutely massive to being with, which Leeds for example in the north of England is decidedly not.  As I implied, there is a superior zero-carbon alternative in the works and it will emerge as a truly viable option in the final years of this project's completion. That alternative is electric flight, and it's coming at us pretty fast. Once that really starts to take off, pun intended, there will be so many vertiports and so many electric planes zipping around England. I think it would be very smart to place such an airport within easy walking distance of the Chunnel- so it's very easy to arrive in London by train and then fly to pretty much any other city that you want. Electric flight is going to be incredibly cost effective- more than ten times cheaper per flight hour than the flights that we are accustomed to. Electric planes will be short range and they won't have a large capacity at first, but that's just fine for the size of England and for the amount of air traffic that there is likely to be. Airports only take up the land that they take off and land from as well. You don't need to build a whole project all the way from A to B- just fly through the air.  Right about the time that this high speed rail project runs into its final delays, the viability of electric flight is going to become perfectly obvious. It will promise to connect any city in England of almost any size, as long as they have a small regional airport. Tickets will very likely be cheaper than for this rail line, there won't be huge projects that are overly costly, and people will still be able to travel at 200 km per hour or more from end to end while having zero carbon emissions. There's far more future upside for electric flight as well- there is more innovation to be had as speed and capacity increases.   Like I said, the timing for this could not be worse. Before it's even completed, a zero emission competitor will emerge as a clearly superior option and a city like Leeds may find that they're just fine without the rail connection. Oh, one last side note- electric planes are expected to generate about one third the amount of noise that comparably sized traditional planes now produce, so that's going to completely change the dynamic of living near an airport. Or vertiport, as the case may be. When electric flight gets going, there will be So many high paid people from London that will choose to work mostly remotely, move to a less expensive place that's 200 to 300 km away, and make a point of living within 10 or 15 minutes of an airport with electric flight that can take them back to London once a week or a couple of times a month- whatever they need. They'll be able to make the trip in about an hour, including time spent getting through the airport which should be relatively fast at a regional airport, and that travel time will improve rather quickly over the years. On top of that, they'll pay less than half the price for a comparable flight using present technology- and it will probably be less expensive than the price point for a high speed rail ticket. Those who set these things up and build the infrastructure won't have to spend nearly as much or put up with these delays, and investors will see good ROI in relatively short order.   This high speed rail project- not all of them in all places at all times, but this particular one at this time- is going to look so stupid in about 5 years' time. The English and especially Londoners will look back on this with so much regret.

Can we just clarify something here for those who say the money could be spent on something else.   There isn't a big pot of money labelled HS2 sitting on a shelf in some dark corner of a stationary cupboard at the Treasury. And there never was. If HS2 isn't built or completed, that imaginary pot of money doesn't then get relabelled 'schools' or 'housing' or 'hospitals'   Capex funding for such a project is provided through borrowing. That money borrowed is secured against future ticket sales and other revenue generated through HS2. Now the question should be, 'how long would that take?' Who knows? I don't know. Does anyone know?  Similarly, that borrowing will also be mitigated against tangible economic growth and benefit in key areas.  One could argue, predictably, much of that will be London; but that's for a different debate. Intangible benefits such as environmental, would also provide another mitigation route.  For example, how much, if any, freight will migrate from road and to rail as a result of the freeing up of space on existing conventional rail routes?  No one doubts the cost benefit analysis has seen a reduction in the ratios from the original forecasts back in 2012 to when work commenced. Mainly as a result of rising costs. About all that commentary on the cost increases, and just the enourmous budget for such a project.  Here's a little factoid on the REAL value of such grand civil engineering projects:  In the Bay Area of California, a 'commuter' rail was built in the 1960's - the Bay Area Rapid Transit District - BART - to connect San Francisco with the (soon to be built suburbs in the coming decades) the East Bay region across the San Francisco Bay. (Basically a cummuter rail from the suburbs into the downtown San Francisco business district.)  Underground stations were only to be built (in the original plans/edition) in San Francisco (3), Oakland (2) and Berkeley (1).  The rest of the East Bay was to have the trains travel on elevated platforms throughout.  Unlike other East Bay cities, the city of Berkeley citizens did not want those raised railways dividing their city.  So a ballot measure was voted on, to underground the railway throughout the entire city, and build the other two BART stations in Berkelely underground.    The cost of building a subway through the city and the two underground stations was considered extremely expensive for the time.  Much handwringing at the time at that cost.  The cost to build that subway and underground starion:  $17 million.  Today, BART couldln't build an elevator for one of its stations for that.  Bottom line - while all of this nashing about the "costs" of building large civil engineering project, what is lost is that these projects are not for use for mere decades, but are on a century scale.    The video is well done.  However, a suggestion for the authors would be to add in some perspective such as what was the budget for the railways built in the 1800's.  I would fathom it would be in the ¬£1,000's and not the ¬£Billions for today's budget.  That comparison alone would give folks a bit of perspective on whether things are 'expensive' or not.     Also, as well pointed out in the comments here, a lot of that money spent does circulate in the country, if not the local economies, so the country as a whole will see it returned.  (In other words, the workers get paid, and pay taxes, etc.)  And, the cost of payback for a larger project is generally spread out over decades too - not just all in the next year or so. The thing about high-speed rail is that you cannot easily compare countries. It was pioneered in Europe by Italy in the 1970s, followed shortly thereafter by France, and later Germany and Spain. Italy was a natural candidate, it being a long and relatively narrow country, with major population areas more or less in a line across the length of it. France is relatively sparsely populated (by European standards at least), and again it makes sense to build these lines. Spain has basically all its major cities on the coast, with the exception of Madrid, so again a high-speed rail network makes sense (although questions have been raised about the cost/benefit ratio there as well).  In the Netherlands, about half of the population lives on about 1/7th of the surface, in the west. There are some population centres in the south, but especially the north is sparsely populated. And it's the north that has been asking for a better railway connection with the west. Until relatively recently, train journeys would travel around what used to be a big inland sea, because hardly any railway construction has taken place since the 1930s, and in the 1930s that inland sea had only just become a lake.  There were calls for conventional high-speed rail, and even for a maglev train. Costs would have been understandably very high. But when the Dutch built the HSL Zuid (Hogesnelheidslijn Zuid: High-Speed Line South) to Belgium and France, and the freight-only Betuweroute to Germany, and both went massively over budget ‚Äì partially because of tunnels to protect animals and the environment ‚Äì the public support for such infrastructure projects collapsed. So when it came to the HSL Oost (High-Speed Line East, to Germany) and any fast connection to the north, the government decided: "Yeah, we're not going to do this."  I wonder how much was taken from the UK's eastern neighbour when it cake to the decision process around HS2. The Dutch are generally excellent at infrastructure engineering, so if they muck it up, it should serve as a warning. And when it comes to Crossrail/Elizabeth Line, that has seen its budget balloon as well.  Don't get me wrong, high-speed rail generally creates large economic benefit in the long term. Japan is an excellent example, and in France, people can live further away and just commute into Paris on a TGV. But ¬£100,000,000,000, or whatever it's going to cost, is a very, very large amount of money. And it will take a very long time to earn it back.  The north of the Netherlands did get a somewhat faster connection, though. The Dutch built the largest artificial island in what used to be sea, and is now a lake. And a couple of years ago, they finished a brand new railway line that runs across this island. It is, in fact, the fastest section of track in the Netherlands, with a line speed of 200 km/h, although no Dutch trains run that fast (yet). The time gained is between 15 and 20 minutes, which may not seem much, but considering how insanely intense the Dutch railway network is being used, is not bad at all.
