The issue I have with HS2 isn't the cost so much as the fact that if they're going to spend ¬£100 billion on something they'd might as well spend another ¬£100 billion whilst they're at it and do it properly and create not just a high speed line but a full on Network.  The trouble with HS2 as it currently stands is that it's a complete Frankenstein of a project in which the scope and aims have changed so many times that what's now expected to be delivered is costing huge amounts of money and won't deliver the most basic of initial goals. Euston was chosen as the station for HS2 because it was the WCML terminus already and that makes some sort of sense, but Euston faces n North and politicians decided that they wanted the lone to go west from London to serve Heathrow... Which it now won't but the plans for traveling west from central London weren't amended.  We do however get Old Oak Common station instead though for connections to Heathrow and to CrossRail. A fantastic idea and very sensible... But could they not have then cut out a middle man there and made Paddington the terminus if serving Heathrow was that important?  No? That's fine I guess, but then why retain Euston? If connectivity with CrossRail and Heathrow at Old Oak Common is that important then why is the terminus not at Kings Cross/St Pancras where you have connections to Thameslink (which is much more far reaching than CrossRail), has connections to both Luton and Gatwick airports, to more underground lines and to Eurostar.  In the Chilterns a station should be built to allow connections to East-West rail.  Further north, what specifically is the aim of Birmingham Interchange? It isn't integrated with the existing Birmingham International station, and mostly serves Birmingham NEC and airport, but is a direct connection to them from London and Manchester really needed? London and Manchester both already have their own airports and exhibition spaces so I can't see demand for the station being that high. Surely there station should be cut and service to the existing station improved using the capacity freed up by HS2.  Curzon Street is possibly the worst offender as a station that shouldn't be built. Having a terminus station in a city which is a huge transit hub is madness of the highest order. Preventing through running of cross country services using HS2's tracks and necessitating not just a change in train but change in station for so many journeys completely misses one of the biggest things HS2 ought to be for - connectivity! What Birmingham needs for HS2 is very expensive and very difficult, but it needs New Street to be either completely rebuilt or for new underground platforms there to provide the centre of an X shaped High Speed Network. The current HS2 plans would form the Southeastern (towards London) and Northwesterm (Towards Crewe/Manchester) legs, and the Northeastern leg could be built as far as East Midlands Parkway pending a decision on how best to continue with serving the Northeast. The final Southwestern leg on the X should be built out of Birmingham to connect to existing Cross-country lines for the moment with a view to future high speed expansion to Cardiff and Bristol, and then on to Exeter and Plymouth. Expensive to do, I'm sure, but if we're spending 100 billion anyway then why the hell are we building something subpar and which is clearly a mistake.  Like Birmingham, a terminus in Manchester is the wrong idea. Piccadilly already struggles with through capacity so building more terminating platforms is again missing the point of HS2 entirely. Manchester needs a through station where HS2 trains can continue North to Scotland from Manchester, not just from London and Birmingham, thus massively increasing frequency and capacity of journeys on Manchester to Scotland direct trains.  The Eastern leg just needs to connect Nottingham, Sheffield, Leeds and then connect to the ECML somewhere North of Leeds for through service to Newcastle and Scotland.  ... And if you're not willing to spend the extra to do all that then for heaven's sake, stop! Decide what your budget is, go back to the drawing board and figure out what the best you can do for that budget is. Potentially use the M1 corridor as the basis of a new London-Scotland line with Birmingham and Manchester branches. Not as much speed but no doubt much better mileage for your money than the current plan

Great quality production - with some excellent balanced reporting and interviews. Only criticism (considering the teaser question 'Is Europe's largest infrastructure project worth it?) is the lack of scrutiny into the economic argument - which has surely weakened as much as the costs have risen. An interesting fact no-one seems to have pointed out is that these mega-projects often get approved based on the idea they'll benefit the entire country. HS2 has (or had) spurs to Manchester and Leeds, which were used to convince MPs of Northern England that their constituencies would be connected. Of course, once the Parliamentary votes are obtained, everything changes. Northern spurs have been downgraded or cancelled and only Phase 1 (Birmingham - London) is guaranteed to be built. So once again, Northern England has been taken advantage to build an infrastructure project that will, once it is finally complete, overwhelmingly benefit the South, which already takes the lion's share of infrastructure spending anyway. This shouldn't be a surprise - in fact it's already happened with another railway mega-project - HS1 and the Channel Tunnel. The same thing happened - Northern MPs were promised that the line would reach as far as Manchester (Eurostar even promised to build a maintenance depot for their trains there), but once the votes were secured and the project went inevitably overbudget, the Manchester spur was cancelled and HS1 only got as far as London. Again. THAT is why there is so much scepticism about this, particular project. The fact it started in London, not Leeds or Manchester ( the Oakervee Review actually recommended that Phase 2 start building down from the North in parallel to Phase 1) is one of the BIG reasons why this project has 'divided a nation'. London will benefit from another world-class infrastructure project, while the promises made to the North evaporate and we're left to make do with our Victorian infrastructure. Incidentally, HS3, a line running east-west, connecting the cities of the North (Liverpool, Manchester, Leeds, Hull), which would have nothing to do with London was shelved last year. So much for all the 'levelling up' propaganda from the government. Plus ca change...

Moreover, if a speed decrease was implemented, the project could be significantly cheaper; namely by not needing as much viaducts - which increase the project's price, and also the maintenance in long-term. Yes, the travel time would be increased - but just look at what is planned now for Leeds? Furthermore, another issue - which was not discussed on the video - is that the new proposed trip from London to Leeds will mandate a train switch, as you will travel initially on a high-speed train, and then switch to a slower train to the final trip to Leeds. This train switch has a very negative impact on demand, i.e., people either look for another mean of transport, or do not travel at all, if the number of switches are too many, e.g., car to metro, metro to train, train to train, train to metro, metro to foot. Such efforts are most certainly scalable, providing government keeps out of the way. The massive benefit to "mega projects" being privately-funded is that proper due diligence is done, with an iron grip kept on costs, because they don't have an endlessly-deep public pocket to stick their hand into.  I realize the "average person" can't conceive of things like mega projects, (highways, railways, airports, ports), health, the police, schools and other "public institutions" being run privately, but that's only because we've been brainwashed out of that thinking. A big part of the problem seem to be the very high costs per km in the UK. In Germany, France and especially in Spain, costs per km are much lower, even for dedicated high speed lines. The German approach of upgrading a lot of existing lines and having slightly lower maximum speeds is even more cost effective. It's worth noting that HS2's cost is based on borrowing against future returns. Since the economic benefits are net positive, it should pay for itself within a few decades after opening through the increased tax revenue. If it wasn't built that revenue wouldn't exist, and thus the money wouldn't exist either.  Imagine you were planning to build a house to rent out. The bank lends you say ¬£200,000 in a house building mortgage because it expects you to be able to pay that via renting it. If you weren't building the house, the bank wouldn't just give you ¬£200k. In essence, this money would never exist. When banks lend you money, they don't give you money they hold, they create it by adding it to your account. They are only required to hold a small fraction of that amount as a reserve. And for governments it's even easier since there is no reserve amount, they can borrow whatever they want, only really dependent on inflation.
Projects that take this long to complete and cost this much end up not being as useful eventually as they could've been in my opinion, as in almost 20 years time the idea of travel or why we would need to travel would change, as well as the means of travel or getting things delivered to us. They've essentially gone neck deep in this and even if they internally realise it could be a relative failure, they have no choice but to complete it.

Large-scale transit projects are always a problem. Politicians love announcing them as they are extremely popular, and offer transformative improvements, however their construction times are longer than the usual political horizon - a decade or more, long after the original set of politicians are out. Then there's budgets. These projects never stay in-budget. It's as if the original budgets are just there to sell the project with the expectation that there will be monumental cost-overruns. This is a problem kicked down the road to the next government who are stuck with the albatross and have to make a tough decision - cancel it and stop the hemorrhaging, or double-down and see it through. The former basically makes all that effort, time, and money a total waste, the latter means more costly overruns and years more of construction. I'm not saying we shouldn't do these projects, quite the contrary, I believe they MUST be done. They are just hilariously difficult to realize.  Over here in Ontario, Canada, public transit projects are a bit of a running joke. One politician will promise one, break ground, then the next one cancels it leading to nothing. It's to the point where a promised public transit project is just considered vaporware from the outset, there to get votes, then promptly forgotten about after they've got or retained their seat.

Economic benefits, being able to live in more affordable housing and commute to jobs in the major cities, and creating more capacity for getting between cities are all major factors in justifying California's high speed rail line between Los Angeles and San Francisco. LA to SF is the second busiest flight in the US, with over 35,000 flights in 2019, and California's population is projected to keep growing to 45 million people by 2050. There are many reasons why California needs a high speed rail line connecting its two major population centers, the LA Basin and SF Bay Area, via its fastest growing region in the Central Valley. Those reasons don't seem to take away from the fact that the project is over a decade behind schedule and currently projected to cost nearly three times its original budget ($93 billion is CAHSR's latest base cost estimate for SF-LA/Anaheim, while $113 billion is the high end estimate, according to CAHSR's 2022 Business Plan), which only fuels the opposition and their endless barrage of negativity towards it, regardless of the physical and other progress it continues to make.   The Tokaido Shinkansen between Tokyo and Osaka was namely built not necessarily for faster speed, but to ease congestion on the busy Tokaido Main Line which was reaching capacity. Even to this day the Shinkansen's success is its ability to move large amounts of people quickly and efficiently, and also safely. During it's nearly 60 years in operation it's carried over 10 billion passengers without a single operations-related fatality. It's easily one of the most successful high speed rail lines ever built, and kickstarted the high speed rail revolution that has swept the world. It too ran over budget and faced staunch opposition.   Projects like HS2 and CAHSR show just how challenging it is nowadays to build the kinds of large-scale infrastructure that was so transformative in the 19th and 20th centuries. China would seem to be proving the opposite, quickly leaving the rest of the world behind as it continuously accelerates to build more highways and high speed rail lines, though it doesn't have as many rules and regulations that projects in other parts of the world like Europe and the US have to deal with. The challenges though shouldn't detract from how beneficial such projects can be, maybe not for the current generation building them but for the ones that follow.   Think of it like planting trees: you may never see them grow up but their shade and possible fruit will benefit those that come after you. Like the projects of long ago, we need to look toward tomorrow, not just today, and consider what kind of world we want to leave behind for our descendants.

To a large degree, upgrades to existing rail links and some track straightening would have likely been a more cost effective strategy compared to splurging on a completely new link. A few strategically placed viaducts to make trains able to go from one track over to another without having to occupy the tracks in between can likewise make massive overall capacity improvements for relatively low cost.  I however don't live in England so it isn't my budget.  But an example to look at is Stockholm, it has 4 train tracks on the south side, 4 on the north, but for a long time only had 2 tracks through the city itself, causing a major bottleneck for the whole network. The solution were to remove the regional trains and give them their own underground train line through town, both giving the commuter trains 2 new stations, but also removing their burden from the existing lines while also providing additional capacity for train traffic. As part of the project a viaduct were also constructed on the south side of town to help trains cross from one side of the tracks to the other. It were however still a massive project, but removed one fairly decent bottleneck from the overall network.  Likewise is Seden also working on a fair few other minor track upgrades that helps increase track speeds and capacity. This is both through making more double tracked rail, but also track straightening to increase speeds.  Now, even if one has double track already, there is nothing saying one can't work on getting a third track into place, or even a fourth if needed. It is also wise to minimize trains occupying/blocking tracks they won't run along. So making either underpasses/tunnels, or viaducts to help trains over to the other side of the tracks is a thing to consider.  For single track rail, a major improvement a lot of countries don't have is just dynamic passing loops. Make the passing loop long enough for the "waiting" train to remain at speed through the loop as the passing train goes past. This alone can shave off a fair few minutes from travel times.

Top video... Things that get forgotten a bit... London and the South East commuter belt has arguably around 20 million people to move around - that's *one third* of the total UK population a lot of congestion on roads without a big rail network. Londoners also pay a lot - unlike many countries, commuter rail isn't really subsidised in the south east (eg my old 20 minute commute from St Albans was nearly ¬£4,000!). London didn't always have a reliable network. In the 1990s it was falling apart, after a decade of poor investment. The Tube was in a mess. And London was losing business to other global hubs. Remember that the King's Cross fire was in 1987 - and that was partly due to old equipment and metro standards. I'm all for the North getting a lot, lot more transport investment, it's just not a simple 'one vs the other'. Also forgotten... Yes, HS2 created passenger capacity on very congestion routes, but it also *frees up* capacity on the old West Coast line for fast-growing cities like Milton Keynes, which can introduce new commuter services to London, etc. Costs for Crossrail became massively inflated as more and more consultancies piled in. The whole procurement and management process in the UK needs to be reviewed. And planning has to take into account the climate crisis, but we have to be balanced about road traffic vs greener transport and energy - the planning system has to catch up. In reality, a lot of the objections are NIMBYs fortunate to live in incredibly prosperous rural areas between London and Birmingham. The time lines are crazy. The whole new system, including HS3/Crossrail North / Northern Powerhouse Rail, needs to be completed in 15 years, alongside real time / location road charging, and a massive national segregated  cycling and walking network.

Curzon St will not be an interchange and will add ~20 mins to a journey from say, Wolverhampton to London (using local lines then hs2).  Regarding capacity, those who regularly use other lines should expect more trains, but at the expense of speed, so I understand it. The point I feel gets lost in the talk about "cost overruns" is that most of that added cost is labor. You're not doubling or tripling the material and land costs. It's mostly driven by more people spending more hours on the project. Those labor costs go directly back into the local economy because the people working on the project have a steady income which allows them to buy more goods and services. They pay taxes on that income, and taxes are collected when they spend money, so all of that cycles back into tax revenue even before the project is complete. Sure, some of those people would find other employment if the project was cancelled, but for the most part cancelling the project would be like several major factories closing down and the sudden unemployment hit would add to the overall economic cost of not finishing the project.

It's not that HS2 is a bad concept, it's that the political management of the project has been irredeemably bad. You only need to look at the electrification of the GWML to see how rail projects in the UK are shockingly managed.  There's no proper planning or budgeting oversight. Contractors engage in absurd levels of overengineering knowing that the govt will just sign off unquestioningly, so costs explode out of control. Most big contractors in the UK have a deeply incestuous relationship with both Tories (particularly) and Labour (to a lesser degree but still very problematic) allowing for rampant corruption, either legalised or grey. This led to absurdities like the almost entirely derelict Acton-Northolt line, which takes an arrow straight path through west london that runs right from North Oak Common being ignored in favour of massively long expensive bored tunnel under west London, rather than doing the obvious and far, far simpler and cheaper option of re-using the existing alignment.  At the same time, the UK approaches projects as individual episodes. There's no long term rolling plan for rail improvements so there is no embedded, retained skill set and know-how about the engineering and project management that exists in many other countries. For example, Spain has turned high speed rail projects into a de-facto production line system and has achieved some of the lowest costs per KM for HSR projects anywhere in the OECD.  Meanwhile, the business case for long distance commuting using HS2 has disappeared, while the line doesn't address the appalling state of local urban rail outside of London. By and large, intercity rail in the UK is pretty good, it's commuter rail outside of London that are terrible. HS2 is literally answering the wrong question, and it's not even doing that in a very good way.

Your explanation of how governments get the power to spend sums like this skimmed over the astonishing details of our long-ago outdated electoral system.   For the UK general election in 2019 there were about 46.5m people registered to vote.  Of those about 67% actually voted. So, about 31m people actually used their vote.  Of those who voted, just under 14m voted Conservative.  So, of those eligible to vote, only about 30% voted for the Conservative government we now have. But, our very outdated electoral system gives them 5 years to enact whatever they want and nobody can stop them - for example deciding to spend the kind of sums we're talking about here.   In overall terms, 20% of the 69m people in the UK population (voters or not voters) wanted a government that gained absolute power for 5 years. *It's not taxpayer money.* That's what everyone seems to forget about this: it's being funded through capital expenditure, essentially borrowing against a future return on investment. We wouldn't be saving money by not building it, because the money essentially doesn't exist until it's invested in something real: the rails, the stations, the trains, and the jobs. You can't point to a single penny in your tax bill that goes towards major new infrastructure projects; it was the same with Crossrail.   Also, the entire carbon footprint of building HS2 is equivalent to one month of emissions from road transport. Given the immense potential of the railway to take cars off the roads, both directly and indirectly through releasing capacity on the existing network, I'd say that's a price worth paying.
